												Carrier Command: Gaea Mission is ultimately a good (not great) game that blends strategy, tactics and action, but it suffers from the most god-awful annoying campaign I think I have ever played.You'll hear a lot about the bad bad BAD script and voice acting, but the campaign is terribly paced too, being, as it seems it was intended, a very, very long tutorial for the Strategy Game option. Having said that, I persevered with the Campaign, and after you take Fulcrum and push into the enemy's territory, which is around the same time you unlock missiles for your Mantas—and around the time the AI starts pushing back!—the game finally lives up to its promise and gets awesome.Taking the islands become a real tactical challenge each time, and your strategy of which islands should be Production, Mining and (oh so important) Defense becomes critical to success. When you get to that point, the Campaign is actually pretty good and the game finally lives up to its potential.Whether or not you can stick it out that long is another story...I have a LOT of love and nostalgia for Carrier Command, having played it ad nauseum on my Amiga when I was a kid, but without that good will, I'm not sure I would have had the gumption to push through the bad bad BAD start of the Campaign game. If you can, though, I think you'll find you are rewarded.Subjective Assessment: 7/10

												+ Very nice graphics.+ Command interface is easy to use.+ Various gameplay improvements over the original.- Tacked on "story" mode.- No multiplayer.- Broken pathfinding.The GoodThe original Carrier Command, while primitive by modern standards, was a really good game for it's time. A good combination of strategy and action. BIS has rebooted this game and fixed many shortcomings of the original's design...well, almost.First thing I will say is that the graphics are very nice. There is a "film grain" effect you cannot turn off, but that aside, I have no complaints whatsoever. The models of the carrier look awesome and the animations are pretty solid. Good job BIS!The interface has also had a huge overhaul since the original. Commanding units is very easy to do (once you get the hang of it). I get a feeling this was designed with consoles in mind, however it works fine on PC, so again no complaints from me.I'd also like to praise the unit customisation added to gameplay. You can now outfit your Mantas and Walruses with different armour and weaponry to engage threats more effectively...but sadly, this is where the praise ends.The BadThe story mode is just a glorified tutorial with bad voice acting. Some parts of it are good for learning the game - the sole reason I played all the way through it was to prepare me for the REAL game; Strategy Mode.The lack of multiplayer is also quite disappointing. Why this was not implemented is not clear - some forum posts suggest it was axed due to development costs, other say it was to be added in a later patch. I personally suspect the former was more likely the case. Either way, it's a pity as multiplayer could have probably boosted the sales of the game.The UglyThe Walrus pathfinding is so bad it's not even funny. Mantas are OK, but Walruses have trouble driving in a straight line. I've tried every patch released since day one and some third party mods, but nothing works. I'm not exaggerating here, feel free to look it up on YouTube.Final ThoughtsThe pathfinding is the deal-breaker for me. The lack of multiplayer and the lame story mode I can forgive, but not this. The amount of sheer frustration I've had just trying to get units to get from point A to point B is too much. It's highly unlikely that BIS will ever fix this - they've released seven patches already and still can't get it right.VERDICT: Don't bother.

												I won't critize the game for its poor production values (voice acting, facial animation, animation in general, props, textures), but I will critize its A.I. because the game is based on it.You see, if you make A.I. movement a core component of your game, you'd better make sure your A.I. systems and pathfinding are at least generally competent - capable of doing basic tasks. The A.I. in this game can be called many things, but "competent" isn't one of them. Which is a problem, because if you have to manually move every single unit because it manages to get stuck every 200 metres, the game becomes a chore (this gets borderline hilarious at the first muddy island - the one where you get the flying unit for the first time - where a more complex level topology and mud makes for a physically painful experience instead of fun). Now don't get me wrong, programming competent realtime A.I. is one of the hardest programming challenges, but that's the thing - if you can't do it properly, don't even try, because it will end badly. They could have try to work around the A.I. by designing the game differently, instead they went in guns blazing and just failed to deliver...

												Back in 1988 a company known as Realtime Games created a game called Carrier Command for multiple home computers such as the Amiga, ZX Spectrum, and Commodore 64. A crossover between a vehicle simulation game and a real-time strategy game, players were tasked with colonizing multiple islands in an archipelago and destroy the enemy aircraft carrier before they can colonize the archipelago themselves. The game was well received receiving high marks from various publications, and gaming magazine The Games Machine even awarded it the number one game of 1988. In 2012 Bohemia Interactive released Carrier Command: Gaea Mission, a modern remake of the original Carrier Command. Did the game hold up over all these years?For starters, I’ve never played the original Carrier Command, so I can’t really compare the original to the remake.  From what I can tell, the main goal of Carrier Command’s campaign is to take control of various islands on the planetoid Taurus in a war between two factions: the United Earth Coalition and the Asian Pacific Alliance. The Campaign portion of the game starts out with you leading an attack on a moon called Taurus in an attempt to take control of it for its resources, to help sway the battle against forces who have taken over Earth. Unfortunately something goes wrong and your squadron crashes on the moon and only a few survive. From there you set out on foot with another soldier who guides you as you roam about in a FPS-style game. Your first goal is to make your way to a damaged carrier. You will venture through a very linear path with just one gun, shooting at very generic looking robots. After this short and dull FPS sequence, I came across the first vehicle in the game. My squadmates started directing me how to control the vehicle and what I could do with it. I found that controlling it was difficult using a mouse and keyboard, so I switched over to using a game controller, where one analog stick steered and the other aimed my gun. Playing with a controller honestly felt more rewarding. Your ground vehicle’s health, fuel and ammo could be topped up by just driving up to various refilling stations shown on the map and pressing the right button. Topping off the vehicles various items is quick, which came in handy when you are on the run. You have two viewing choices when moving your vehicles: a first person or 3rd person view. I stuck mainly with the third-person camera angle because you need to see more of the surrounding area so you don’t suddenly find yourself sliding down a hill, out of control.After becoming familiar with your new toy, you eventually make your way to the damaged carrier, dock at its side, and make your way inside. Once again you are back on foot in a short FPS segment taking out more robots. After all the robots are cleared, the surviving soldiers join you on the carrier, and you take command of the ship which turns out to be completely remote controlled, so you don’t need to leave your command chair. However, the carrier is badly damaged and in need of repair. So from your new seat you are able to remotely control the vehicle that brought you to the carrier.  You wil then drive it to the nearest island on your map to search for supplies. This is where the game’s focus shifts to the main campaign where you will be taking over various islands you come across by hacking into base computers. I quickly found that this is not that simple because all the islands have defenses in the form of ground roaming robots, vehicles, as well as small and speedy airships. Not to mention most of the bases have gun turrets. Much of the time you will be running around activating switches to shut things down to gain access to areas and bypass enemy defences. Different islands have different properties: some have production facilities which will produce new equipment or vehicles; others are rich in resources that you need to repair your carrier and produce your equipment. There are up to 33 islands in the game all with various environments. Some can be swampy, others more temperate and others more desert-like. In the swampy areas it is really hard to control ground assaults as you slip and slide in the mud and wet grass. This is where a real time strategy-like gameplay element comes into play as you dive deeper into the game. Some islands get tricky and require you to have more than one vehicle on the go. You can have up to four ground and four air vehicles executing orders at the same time, each equipped with various guns and devices that you produce to aid you in taking over the island in question. I found the AI for the game as a whole to be very hit or miss, with spots of brilliance followed by some completely bizarre behaviour.Other than the main campaign, you have one other mode called “Strategy Game”. Here you are pitted against the computer in a large randomly-generated battle, but you have various settings at your disposal like the number of islands, enemy strength, what resources you start up with and how fast islands generate the materials you need. You can also set winning conditions too, like a number of carriers destroyed, or islands that need to be taken over. It’s a fun mode if you want to avoid the single player story and get into the thick of things quickly. In terms of the visuals, the game is nice to look at, but nothing blew me away. Weather and environmental effects are nicely done and you can see a bit of influence from the ARMA series in it. I did experience some weird clipping issues while driving vehicles. I would be driving along and suddenly part of the screen would flash like I drove through something. The music in the game is odd. It’s very big and orchestra-sounding with a large choir, but it only plays at certain times. The rest of the time it’s just environmental sound effects mixed with sounds of vehicles and gunfire. Voiceovers from the characters work quite well, and no one seems to be overacting their roles, but as you progress through the game you do get somewhat tired of hearing what they have to say.For a game that attempts to mix in some First Person Shooter sequences with some Real Time Strategy elements, Bohemia Interactive did a decent job. Unfortunately, the overall experience falls a little short due to some of the issues with the AI as well as the lack of any multiplayer and some technical issues.

Carrier Command: Gaea Mission - game with a huge, perfectly wasted potential. This is one of a few games in my library that I regret much about not just buying, but even wasting time on completing it. 												This game is very under rated... It is a mixture of tactical gameplay and action gameplay and works really well. It falls short of being a masterpiece because of a few issues, but it wasn't too far in my opinion. I mostly play the Campaign so haven't done many Skirmishes. The story and voice acting is quite low budget, but the focus is on the gameplay anyway. The music is great and the graphics are nice. The controls and physics are good in this game, vehicles feel solid, weight affects their speed so what you equip them with has an impact, they slip on mud, they struggle up steep hills and whizz down the other side etc. It is realistic and handles well. The gameplay overall is good but not great. You have to capture a series of islands, so you travel there in your uber Aircraft Carrier, and then you launch some flying pew pew pew craft to scout the island and work out where all the resources are etc. The flying craft are weak though so you have to use them to scout carefully and then get them back to safety. Later in the game you get to use them more to shoot or bomb key targets, but early in the game they are only really used as scouts. Then you launch your tanks which will do all the capturing. You can have 4 tanks and each one can have a few gear upgrades of your choice, heavier armour that makes them slower but tankier, a variety of weapons, a hacking device, etc. The campaign is slow to get going, the first dozen or so islands you have to do with basic gear, but it gets more interesting later on when you get to start using your carrier's big guns, and your units get more interesting weapons like the gattling gun and your can drop bombs from the flying units etc.Capturing the islands is done by driving around and capturing mini bases all over the island, and killing anything that gets in your way - preferably by waiting for your squad to keep up with you so you can get the benefit of all their firepower at once. Sometimes there are fixed turrets shooting at you, sometimes a bunch of robots come at you, and sometimes some vehicles or aircraft come at you. Occasionally you have to deal with all of those at once, but you can tend to pick stuff off bit by bit if you go slow and steady, especially earlier in the game. Also you can park your flying craft nearby and you can use those to help you finish off stuff once the main defences are dead. This capturing of the islands is the bulk of the game and it is fun, but this is the part of the game I think should have been a bit better. It isn't bad by any means, but it could have been better, and there other bits of gameplay I think they should have ignored and instead just focused on this part of the game. You also have to manage your carrier in the meantime, building gear to replace whatever you lose in battle, and generating more fuel, etc. There is a little bit of strategy with the island capturing too, because you can choose if the island should produce stuff, mine stuff, or be a defensive island, so depending where on the map it is, you can use this to your advantage. Although the game doesn't seem to focus on this enough in the Campaign at least. Overall it is fun and actiony, but it does fall short from greatness in several ways and I'll try to explain. First off, as you can see from a lot of the negative reviews, some people try to play the game as a tactical RTS type game. Technically the game should have let people do that, but the AI just isn't up to it. The way I play is to take direct control over the main tank, and set the other 3 tanks to follow me, and the game plays fine like that. You somtimes need to wait a moment for them to catch up, but mostly the pathing is fine and the AI does ok at following you and shooting whatever you shoot. The problem is if you want to sit back at the carrier or fly around command the ground units from afar, like a real strategy game, bad things will happen due to pathing and AI failures. They AI and pathing is not terrible, but it isn't good enough to just send things off on their own and expect them to make it. Often they will get whooped by the enemy or stuck on a tree, tumble down a cliff etc.. It is a shame because it could have been a bit more RTS. Personally I don't really care about this though, because if you lead the troops into battle (surely this is the most fun thing to do anyway?), they will follow you just fine. Also the actual capturing of the islands (which is the bulk of what you do) is quite repetitive and shallow and could have been better. Each island might have a different shape, but they all work the exact same way. There are several bases on the island and you have to hack a building or clear out the enemies in each base, and on to the next one, and then you can capture the command center in the final base. Do that then it is on to the next island to repeat, in exactly the same way. It is a bit more interesting in that you unlock better gear as you make progress, and in the campaign especially, this can make the game quite addictive. You start with very basic basics, and gradually you unlock many little upgrades. Also the enemy bases start getting tougher and more interesting as you progress through the islands. At first it is just a handful of guys who die with 1 shot. Then you start getting occasional tanks, but later you get fortress style bases with many turrents, ambushes of several enemy tanks, and flying craft all over the place. The game is repetitive, but at least you are repeating fun things, so not a major problem, but to me this is the bulk of the game and it could have used something to jazz up this basic combat.Lastly, there are some wasted opportunities. Clearly they just didn't have the time or budget to do everything they wanted, but it is a shame because there are things that could have fleshed the game out more. Like I said you can customise the islands to do what you want, but there should have been more to this. Also you can actually shoot things from your carrier, but you very rarely get to enjoy this because most of the stuff on each island is inland so it is out of your range. Also you can choose priorities of repairs on your ship, but this hardly ever gets used so it is like a wasted feature. Also you can put different weapons on your tanks but the game doesn't really require you to play smart. The sensible option would be to have 1 of each weapon, so the lazer can blow up stuff, while the anti air cannon guy can you protect you from flying stuff, etc.. etc.. But really, just the lazer alone is enough to deal with everything. Also there are a few FPS on foot sections in the game but they seem a bit weak and gimpy compared to a real FPS. They are not terrible, but a far cry from Halflife 2 or System Shock or something. So there are a lot of under developed features, and I think the game would have benefitted hugely from the devs scaling back all this stuff, and focusing on the key gameplay and making that great instead of ok. Overall it is good game though, and quite a unique experience. If you want deep strategy, or visceral action, look elsewhere. But a blend of both those things is not often seen so this game is worth thinking about. I wish it had better sales because a bigger budget sequel to this game would be a big deal in gaming, especially nowadays. I think the game really suffered from limited marketing, I never even heard about this game until years after release.

An enemy carrier is doing the same. However, CCGM added a few segments where you have to play first person shooter. You sometimes have to control a vehicle directly as well... which makes you wonder "why am I risking my own neck? I'm the captain!"The developers, Bohemia, added some backstory where the UEC is fighting against the APA (apparently mostly Chinese), and UEC is losing, due to lack of water, so they decided to colonize this "Taurus" planet, take its water back to Earth, but obviously APA is there to stop them, and apparently they got there first. You, Lt Myrik, is ordered to land and hopefully make your way to an old carrier, reactivate it, and use it to help you reconquer the islands in the "Dead Zone". The problem with the game is while the starting islands (first 4 or so) do introduce the game to the RTS player, the really important part of the game, such as setting up defenses of the island, so it can survive assaults while you're out island hopping, is left virtually unexplained. You're simply told that you can convert the islands to 'defensive' by building a "defensive module" and rebuilding the command center, but that was too vague. And it doesn't explain how to actually IMPROVE the island's defense rating, which ranges from weak all the way up to "deadly". The ship itself also needs fuel which is also used for damage control / repairs. And the only way you can get fuel to carrier is through fuel packs sent via the cargo barge (submarine) which can also bring you various other goodies from your "stockpile" island where all the stuff your manufacturing went. Transport capacity is limited, and it takes time moving from stockpile to you (and back). The more islands you conquer, the faster your resources accumulate or the faster your manufacturing goes depending on what type of island you got. Pathfinding is a major problem in this game. The AI units have a tough time pathfinding in groups, which makes the game at times, comical. Often you have to assume direct control to push the unit beyond the chokepoint, then the AI does a decent job of pathfinding, but it can't manuever around other friendly ground units. The atrocious pathfinding means you have to micromanage each vehicle for fuel, ammo, and repair, rather than give simple orders like "group fuel" or "group ammo" and see the units take turns by themselves. The vehicles can often even get lost by themselves, often with hilarious results, not to mention some odd physics. Send a vehicle to go from one end of island to another, and it may end up falling off a bridge, or making a 360 turn when a simple left or right turn would do, or get stuck on some rocks. Once, one of my Walrus managed to turn turtle (upside down) in the middle of the ocean on the way to the island. Somehow that makes it move BACKWARDS instead of forwards. (Huh?)  Yet another funny is with the hook. Tried to retrieve a Walrus that ran out of fuel with the hook. Had to be flown manually, and I got too low and the Walrus is dragging in the waves... but I was flying with nose straight into the water, and my VTOL engines were pointing 45 degrees down into the water, yet I'm still moving across the water... dragging the Walrus along. Somehow the hook is still attached. Hahaha. The game tries to mix up the bits by giving you many First-person shooter segments. You need to actually jump out of the vehicle and use your personal weapons, such as assault rifle, laser, and later plasma rifle. Usually, you go into the enemy base and do your various bits of sabotage, raid computer terminals, and so on and so forth. There are a few segments where you have to jog across the whole island. You mainly face battledroids and a few soldiers, but occasionally, turrets and vehicle (but you usually bypass them. The bases are pretty easy as you do have a personal shield and as long as you don't take too many hits at once your shield powers up again much like HALO. However, some bases have regenerating enemies (until you shut that down) and you have to watch out for exploding barrels (which can kill you).  Those segments are just... weird, out of place, even. The end of the game, well, that gets ridiculous really fast. Spoiler ahead. To accomplish the end game, you need to...1) Conquer 2 out of 4 volcanic power plant islands that is supplying the big enemy bastion with shields that damages everything nearby. You need to check all four islands though. 2) Once you've disabled the shield, then you can start the invasion proper, but you're in an FPS segment, where you can take direct control of one of several Walruses, and the others will follow along as AI. You can jump out and change to a different vehicle. You have to secure 7 different "zones" on the island shooting all the bad guys. Fortunately, you do get a "repair walrus" to tag along and repair your squad if you conquer the first zone. 3) Once you secure the final zone (don't run into the forcefield!)  you have to drive up to the research center where you get the control software of the torpedo, and you enjoy a cutscene where the enemy carrier goes to the bottom, but the bad guy is getting away in a Manta (flyer)  so you jump in a Manta and follow him too. 4) The bad guy's Manta has a shield... yours does not. However, you do have a super gatling. You have to chase him amidst enemy defenses (all of them trying to shoot you down), without crashing your flyer into the hills or whatever, while you try to overload his shields, then shoot him. 5) Once you got him down to 20%, a timer starts. He goes one particular path, then heads for his submarine pen where he will escape. You have to kill him (shields and all) before he gets to the pen. 6) The game then turns into a "rail shooter" where you're the gunner and the AI drives, and you have to shoot enemies all along your path... UNTIL the next segment... when your vehicle's toast, but you survived. Then it's...7) Yep, back to first person shooter. Fight your way across the bridge, down a mountain pass, to the submarine pen, for the final cutscene. The game is also quite happy to crash here and there. I'm on a pretty standard setup and the game crashed many times, losing a hour or two of progress each time. Most of the time autosave works, but sometimes, the game just crashed when it tries to load a cutscene. All in all, I should be playing Hostile Waters (which is now available)

												I haven't played very far into this game (see below for why), but man. I was a huge fan of the original Carrier Command back on my Mac Classic computer, and I was excited to see someone remade it. Until I actually tried to play this mess of a game.The game starts with a literally 45-minute-long inexplicable Halo-ripoff first-person shooter section that has absolutely nothing to do with Carrier Command and serves only to confuse the bejeezus out of players. It's also, frankly, not very good at all.If you get past that obstacle, you do finally get into the carrier's captain's seat, you know, that thing that should have happened in the first 30 seconds of the game. However, here the game somehow gets even worse.Your first mission is to take over an enemy island. Ok, fine, that's like 75% of the original Carrier Command's gameplay, so I should feel right at home here. To do so you move the carrier to the island. (Which, BTW, takes ages-- the game supposedly accelerates time, but even despite that it takes a solid few minutes to arrive.) Once there, you equip a Walrus amphibous vehicle with your only command center hacking took and get onto the island.Once there, you have to squint to find the white-on-light-blue waypoint markers the game uses to tell you where to go, assuming you notice them at all which I didn't for the longest time because they're so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed invisible. The Walrus you get lands with almost no fuel, so you first have to find a fuel station. It took me a long time to get past this because the tutorial never tells you:1) What the fuel station looks like (hint: lightning bolt icon)2) That you have to use F to "activate" it and actually refuel. I assumed I was doing it wrong because I was sitting there for ages and nothing happened.Once you've finished that obstacle, your next task is to enter the command center. If you take the direct path, you end up falling down a cliff, destroying the only hacking unit thing, and getting a Game Over. Seriously. This game could not have been playtested even one bit.During your next play through, you telepathically realize you’re supposed to continue down a road that looks on the map like it goes in the entirely opposite direction you want to go. When you do arrive at the command center, a force field seals it off, and here’s where the tutorial really goes off the rails.You have two Walruses and two buttons you have to hit at the same time. The solution is obviously to position one Walrus at each button, then press the buttons quickly to open the force field. The problem is: the second Walrus always follows the first one on autopilot when you switch! So it’s virtually impossible to get them positioned correctly! There are also a lot of quirks the game never tells you about—for example when you get into a Walrus you can’t actually steer it until you tap the throttle with W or S on the keyboard. Until you accidentally discover that, you’ll probably just assume the game is broken like I did. Again: no playtesting whatsoever.I did manage to finish this challenge mostly by accident. Then the tutorial voiceover lady tells you to drive into the command center, quickly get close to the building, and hit the F key to begin hacking. If you do that, you of course get another Game Over, because it’s the entirely wrong thing to do. What you need to do is go slowly, extremely slowly, past the base defenses because it turns out that while you’re hacking, if you get hit by even a single bullet, your progress is reset to zero. There's no point to even starting the hacking until you've taken out all of the robots and turrets defending the base. Of course the game doesn’t tell you this, and of course you assume the tutorial text is correct, so of course you get another Game Over. Then you come here to Steam and write a review of this worthless garbage game.I spent 40 minutes on the first damned mission and wasn’t able to complete it. Partly because the tutorial text doesn’t tell you important things you need to know. Partly because what the tutorial text *does* tell you is a lie. And partly because the AI actively fights against you when you’re trying to complete the level.Unbelievable garbage.

It has stunning graphic, the islands maps are so detailed and well made in order to suit vehicle gameplay that I almost feel like it would be a waste to manage all your units in the RTS map mode. 　But I wouldn't recommend it to others. It's just that I found the gameplay somewhat unrewarding and repetitive. Although you got lots of weapon and modification types, the basic structure of every battle is pretty much the same. You drive your carrier to capture an island, deploy 4 Mantas (hoverplane) and 4 Walruses (armour car) with various weapon and tools and head to the command centre. You don't have any other type of units except those two.　Although the campaign start with a FPS experience, you don't get to play as foot soldiers anymore after the first level. I was expecting the player to be at least able to walk around the commanding bridge of the carrier, staring outside the window as you wait and watch your units coming home, and I was disappointed. Even though you did walk around inside the carrier in the first level. 　You can't move your carrier in anyway besides the preset waypoints of warp positions. You can't direct control anything other than those 4 Mantas, 4 Walruses and a main gun on your carrier, dispite how many droids and turrets defences you own on an island and that even though you did play as a droid in the first level.　There are just too many little disappointments such as these, and too few variations or distractions to keep you entertained besides the main objective, which can be frustrating at times. The game really appeared to be an nice and huge open-world playground, but far too often I feel myself restrained in actual gameplay.　It's a well-made game coming from one of my favourite developers but IMO got loads of wasted potential. I got this game from humble bundle for a few dollars, along with ARMA series I believe, and it's well-worth it. But the full price of $32.99, I don't think so.

												Don't get me wrong, this game is of high quality and brilliant ideas. It has stunning graphic, the islands maps are so detailed and well made in order to suit vehicle gameplay that I almost feel like it would be a waste to manage all your units in the RTS map mode. 　But I wouldn't recommend it to others. It's just that I found the gameplay somewhat unrewarding and repetitive. Although you got lots of weapon and modification types, the basic structure of every battle is pretty much the same. You drive your carrier to capture an island, deploy 4 Mantas (hoverplane) and 4 Walruses (armour car) with various weapon and tools and head to the command centre. You don't have any other type of units except those two.　Although the campaign start with a FPS experience, you don't get to play as foot soldiers anymore after the first level. I was expecting the player to be at least able to walk around the commanding bridge of the carrier, staring outside the window as you wait and watch your units coming home, and I was disappointed. Even though you did walk around inside the carrier in the first level. 　You can't move your carrier in anyway besides the preset waypoints of warp positions. You can't direct control anything other than those 4 Mantas, 4 Walruses and a main gun on your carrier, dispite how many droids and turrets defences you own on an island and that even though you did play as a droid in the first level.　There are just too many little disappointments such as these, and too few variations or distractions to keep you entertained besides the main objective, which can be frustrating at times. The game really appeared to be an nice and huge open-world playground, but far too often I feel myself restrained in actual gameplay.　It's a well-made game coming from one of my favourite developers but IMO got loads of wasted potential. I got this game from humble bundle for a few dollars, along with ARMA series I believe, and it's well-worth it. But the full price of $32.99, I don't think so.

												This game is very much a diamond in the rough. It has a ton of rough edges and desperately needs more developer attention, but it has tons of potential and I've (mostly) enjoyed my time with it.The concept of the game is amazing and mostly works, it's awesome to be able to seamlessly switch between FPS and RTS controls. Unfortunately the AI for your units is pretty bad so you'll have to micromanage them (and frequently take direct control) so they don't get stuck and killed. The poor AI is probably the single biggest issue with the game in its current state.I found the most effective strategy to be to order my units to move to a staging area and take control of one unit at a time to manually chip away at the enemy defenses, retreating after taking too much damage and switching to the next unit and ordering the damaged unit to head back to the carrier for repairs.One area that I would like to see improved is the addition of controllable ground troops for capturing objectives (remote control robotic infantry is available in the campaign for certain scripted missions but is unavailable outside of that) that you would ferry in using the APCs. More variety of vehicle weapons and attachments would be great as well.That said, the current asking price is too high for this game. It is still a beta, don't buy at the $30 asking price, wait for a deep discount (the happen semi frequently) and pick it up then, otherwise you will likely be disappointed due to all the rough edges.

												I have over 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game. One Hour Reviews #32 - Command Carrier: Gaea MissionThis is another example of a very mediocre game from Bohemia Interactive.  The production values are not that great.  The graphics aren't bad, and the sound effects were alright, but honestly I could have just played this with the sound off and been just as happy not to listen to anymore of the voice acting or music.The opening of the campaign just plays like a straight up sci-fi based shooter with some dull characters and story.  But eventually you get command of a carrier, and the game morphs into a real time strategy.  I did not get very far into the strategy part of the game, so I may be missing some of the better parts of the game.   But even in the short time I did play, I could already get a sense of how bad the AI was.  I admit I am not the biggest fan of RTS games to begin with, so if I have to fight my own units AI on top of that, it makes it even more difficult to look forward to.Perhaps fans of the original game will be more forgiving. I actually didn't realize ahead of time this was a remake of a classic game.  Somehow I missed this the first time around.  Now I wish I had missed it the second time as well.

Posted: January 25, 2014
												I have many fond memories of this game's progenitor when I played it on my beloved Amiga A500. The graphics were simple, but functional for the experience of tactical and strategic gameplay. The entire premise of the game was almost like a naval chess battle. When I heard there was a remake in the works I did have expectations that the core of the game would still be there, but in a very modern wrapping. The carrier itself has visually transformed and like all the visuals, is very impressive. The audio is good too, but the execution of this games core is poor. Blending first person shooter elements into the game helps take the stale out of being locked into vehicles, but there's no multiplayer to really validate it. The need to be moving in and out of vehicles and structures feels like a bolt on to a RTS game. Actual vehicle combat is good enough, The AI is thin, pathing for friendly vehicles is often poor, and I've had to manually retrieve a fair few Walrus that got themselves trapped. The enemy doesn't show a great deal more sense, and the challenge they present isn't in their tactics, but their numbers and loadout as you progress through the campaign. I was aching to get my carrier toe-to-toe with the enemy's. I loved brining down the ACC Omega on the original version, but the naval combat is almost pointless, it's mostly defending your own ship from island defences and when you do finally meet your nautical nemesis, you feel like a bug on a windshield. (The originals enemy carrier had weaknesses, the modern version only becomes vunerable after a certain point, beware of this)The two modes of play differ mainly in that one has specific story based missions and goals in a near linear campaign format. The other is more likened to the original, though it's best to point out here that it is a LOT slower leaving an imprssion that playing through it will be an immense chore. This game would have flourished as a multiplayer experience with players piloting or on foot, either in direct engagement or attacking/sabotaging supply lines. I had fun, but couldn't help feeling that they just didn't really go the distance with Carrier Command they could have.Good - Solid visuals, good management and vehicle combat can be a lotta fun.Bad - Cardboard thin depth of play and no multiplayer (and no real excuse for its absence)

												An outstanding update to the original. Carrier Command is a game where you control an advanced carrier which has advanced amphibious tanks and VTOLs with which to slowly capture a series of islands with which to increase your resources and manufacturing capabilities, replenishing supplies and keeping you in the fight.Island management is deeply strategic in not only your choice of base on the island (defence, mining or factory) but in always ensuring multiple supply lines. Islands are now unique, with differing terrain, base layout and so requiring much more strategy to take and hold, often requiring hitting key strategic objectives in order to claim them for your own.The story line is a let down, but a great tutorial to walk you through the mechanics once you get past the opening FPS section. Once you're learned what you need, stick with the free mode and set about conquering the islands on your own terms.The AI pathing can be frustrating at times for the Walruses, but once you 'learn the game' you'll begin plotting multiple point paths to avoid most of the trouble.All in all, a deep and satisfying mix of real time strategy and fast paced vehicle assault action that provides just as many hours of enjoyment as the beloved original.

												I know nothing about the original Carrier Command, so take this review with a grain of salt. Carrier Command: Gaea Mission is primarily a strategy game with first-person elements. What seems to have been an opportunity to harness a very gorgeous and expansive universe is squandered by clunky, non-functioning, or restrictive controls, a narrow and unchangeable field of view and, most egregiously, terrible AI. The fact that the voice acting and the sound effects are poor are nearly forgivable but the fact that the AI - an absolutely essential component of the game - doesn't work is this game's undoing. The AI, through commands that the player gives to units that operate independently due to this game's first-person perspective, should work well enough to perform the tasks delegated to them. They don't. Telling a unit to dock on the carrier does not guarantee that the unit will dock on the carrier. This is important when a unit that is low on health, the death of which means a game over in many cases, because the unit will not take anything resembling an "intelligent route" to the carrier. It will wantonly engage enemy units that it should try to avoid, making the AI entirely unreliable. This is not a good system, because micromanaging the units to the scale needed for them to do their jobs is unreasonable. Even worse, this game requires automated tasks like moving units back to the carrier, to continue the game, which may mean spending a long time just leading units back to the carrier after a mission. Once, I drove one unit manually while allowing the other to navigate itself. I got the controlled unit to the carrier, only to find that the AI controlled unit was repeatedly hitting the side of a bridge, wasting quite some time. These mindless tasks are piled on random tasks that do not serve the "story line" and are clear attempts to prolong the game, and the system that moves the carrier from map to map also takes a long time of doing nothing for absolutely no reason at all. Speaking of the story, the "Story-Driven Campaign" with its "immersive storyline" is more a very long tutorial. The story itself is initially very unclear and does not begin in any manner that could be described as “compelling”.I was excited when I first got Gaea Mission because it looked great and the environments look stunning. Unfortunately, that's the only part of the game that I can bring myself to like.

												Carrier Command: Gaea mission is a Real-Time Strategy game that also allows you to jump into either your air or amphibious land vehicles to capture islands with the goal being either to capture every island on the map and/or destroy your enemy's carrier, or at least that's how I understand it 6 hours in.Like the start of a rollercoaster, you'll start to anticipate how much fun you're going to have with this game: a tech tree (albeit randomized), logistics management, the cameras that show you what your unit sees.  Then the cart flies off the tracks when the Tropic Thunder A.I. that manages your pathfinding clashes with the enemy's Skynet's A.I..  Units equipped with grenade launchers will stand still point their guns in the air upon receiving a command to attack a structure, or straight up murder your own carrier if you deploy them to chase a nearby enemy unit.  Thankfully, the air unit's A.I. is on point, and probably better than your own flight skills.I would be amazed if you could lose an island at all to the A.I., as conquering an enemy island requires you to do a side mission, including fuse-boxing scramblers so that your units can reach the command center, or fuse-boxing firewalls so that capturing a center doesn't take five years.  It's 50/50 that your unit will reach the area and activate the point without getting stuck on a rock or tree.  Units even get tripped up on things as nebulous as water on the main map screen.  By the time you've spent half an hour taking an island the size of five minutes, the game crashes on the very next move you make.  If you won't save your money, at least save your game after every conquest you make here.The game makes other bizzare decisions: You aren't told how long an area you've captured will be ready for production.  You can't speed up time outside of running out of gas and trying to gun it to an island anyway.  An invisible tech tree that you make random progress in when you capture an island or click a factory.The other reviews here are accurate.  I'm not deterred by a few glitches here and there, but this game made me throw in the towel.

Posted: April 10, 2015
												As a player who remembers the original Carrier Command, this game seems like a surprising step back in terms of scope, but it is, fundamentally, quite good fun.Some bugs exist, but can mostly be worked around.  The walrus pathfinding is still unreliable, although nowhere near as bad as it was at launch.  You'll also spend most of your time flying Mantas, rather than driving Walruses as the Mantas have much greater tactical flexibility; if you're wanting to play a drive-and-shoot game, this may not be a great choice.On the other hand, the Mantas handle well, the islands are fun to crack and the unit loadout and upgrade paths are enjoyable to work with.  There's a certain satisfaction to driving a Walrus around armed with flak cannons simply obliterating anything you can get into your crosshairs.  Choosing whether to arm your mantas with missiles to make your life easier, or rockets for greater firepower, but necessitating greater handling skills (which isn't easy when you're dodging missiles yourself) is a choice worth making and if you make a poor choice, you'll find out quickly (and possibly painfully) enough.To do well, you'll have to work out approach and escape routes as often enough you'll find yourself sneaking around a building corner to come face to face with a flak-armed Walrus, having to flee, dropping down to wave-skimming height with Hell's fury erupting around and behind you as you limp back to the carrier to repair and try again.  There's a frisson to these moments that is well worth experiencing.Is it worth the full asking price of £20?  Maybe not, but it's definitely worth playing, and one run through of the Campaign (linear story) and the Strategy Game (non-linear island hopping campaign) will keep you entertained for a fair few hours.  If you're willing to add mods, that might make the Strategy Game worth playing through a second time, but basically all they'll do is increase the difficulty (and remove some possible exploits) as opposed to introducing anything really new.There's a free demo available, so try the game out and work out what price you think the game is worth.  There are plenty of newer games with more bugs and less polish being given far better reviews than this received upon its release.8/10 - Would fly backwards into trees again.

												This is a pre completion review so I focus on game mechanics and overall playability intead of the campaign.Overall the game is made by the people who worked on open world simulators before and it shows similarities with ARMA and so on. Load times are pleasingly short (only good thing), graphics look decent by yesterdays standards and lighting and weather effects are not too demanding so one can say the game wont get any uglier when you turn down high graphics.The settings are alright graphics wise, key remapping is standard simulator stuff with reminders of what key functions will be overwritten so it is best to keep the standard controls on. MOUSE settings are atrocious but at least you can fiddle with horizontal and vertical sensitivity which is good to compensate for the forever accelerated mouse view.Biggest thing against this simulator is the fact that it is far from a simulator. It just dumbs down anything you know from ARMA and makes it controllable with a gamepad (hurr durr thats why theres an extra gamepad settings menu). The squad selection is a ♥♥♥♥♥ and requires you to HOLD Ctrl + 2 trough 9 to select specifically those units which will get orders. Otherwise EVERY unit will receive the quick command orders from the circle selector which you activate with the Space key... oh yeah NO JUMPING, NEVER! This also means, no loopings, dodging or any other stuff you can perform in ANY real simulator be it on foot, in a vehicle or aircraft... HOORAY for Bohemia stooping to these caveman standards of gameplay.To go about your business you equip your units with gear that gets unlocked during campaign or randomly after taking an island ... that's right. You do not control the building process on any of your islands except what special purpose it should focus on (ressources, manufacturing, defence and one single central stockpile island or the island which will  spawn anything you put into production queue) Defence function is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T since it gives you only a few more hours before a well equipped enemy carrier cleans house. BTT: You set waypoints and wait for the brainded AI to steer your units on automatically chosen paths in a single formation which is always a line / convoy... another dumbed down feature but it is probably better because pathfinding is  a real ♥♥♥♥♥! Sometimes you forget to put the command into execute mode and suddenly realize that your spearhead attack unit is alone against a whole base. Autoaim is strong in this game (because its the future ... oh no because it is Bohemia and they cannot ♥♥♥♥ing program merciful AI if their life depended on it... EVERYTHING has AUTOAIM except the player controlled unit. You have to LOOK at the target, check if the reticle is YELLOW (wtf y u no red?) and select the ATTACK order from the cricle menu AND press E for execute... then you watch how awkwardly misplaced gunfire does magical one hit kills or the laser beams get bent in a weird way around your cockpit and magically do damage.The biggest GRIPE I have with the weapons is that they are pretty useless even if you have the superior guns. The AI is too dumb to attack from afar (no comparison to ARMA Tank crews) and the early AA weapons suck♥♥♥♥♥♥because the swarm of bullets you keep spewing is 1 pixel OFF so the target just laughs and keeps dodging and attacking you.The balancing is overall♥♥♥♥♥♥ While on foot in the campaign you can take a lot of shots from enemy droids and infantry but piloting a vehicle or aircraft those droids become a real pain unless you manage to take em out from afar or slam into them. A small group can easily bring down half if not more armor depending on their weapons. HEAT turrets... oh god why!? There is a fire and forget weapon for almost anything. HEAT slugs can oneshot any light armored tank and the AUTOAIM can lead to your whole platoon to be wiped by a SINGLE UNIT! This means most of the time you will have to reload a save (if you saved at all or restart the island since you wont get reinforcements in time to continue where you left off.Your carrier is equipped with a front turret that is made out of the weakest armor in the game. One hit from another plasma turret will wipe it out and the reconstruction takes a LOT of time. The enemy carrier can OUTRUN your aircrafts... thats right. The ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ naval units in this game are as fast as a VTOL and once they are out of radar range THEY MAGICALLY DISAPPEAR -.- Bringing down the enemy carrier is ridiculous. You'll go trough most of your turret ammunition, your idiotic bots can't replenish ammo while the carrier is moving since the pathfinding is TOO DUMB TO LAND on a moving ship (but manually you can do it one by one while flying just above the carrier bay doors)Basically what you do is switch from map to first person or third person camera behind a turret all thetime. To take out turrets you switch to manual control, to kill anything up close you switch back to map and do the trategy game thing (select units then click target) ALL the while the CURSOR moves like it has parkinson disease making you feel like the game runs on 10 FPS ... it is the pinacle of awkward having to manually select everything with mouse acceleration and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ cursor design that (3 times bigger than the unit you want to select (TO APPEAL TO the console RTS crowd ... WTF BOHEMIA?)TL;DRGAME IS PLAYABLE but at the same time a HUGE UNFULLFILING TIME WASTING EXPERIENCE thanks to the ♥♥♥♥♥iest simulator controls ever from the bunch who specialized in making military and squad sims ...They should be ashamed of themselves for wasting this games potential. It could be much less frustrating.

												As a player who remembers the original Carrier Command, this game seems like a surprising step back in terms of scope, but it is, fundamentally, quite good fun.Some bugs exist, but can mostly be worked around.  The walrus pathfinding is still unreliable, although nowhere near as bad as it was at launch.  You'll also spend most of your time flying Mantas, rather than driving Walruses as the Mantas have much greater tactical flexibility; if you're wanting to play a drive-and-shoot game, this may not be a great choice.On the other hand, the Mantas handle well, the islands are fun to crack and the unit loadout and upgrade paths are enjoyable to work with.  There's a certain satisfaction to driving a Walrus around armed with flak cannons simply obliterating anything you can get into your crosshairs.  Choosing whether to arm your mantas with missiles to make your life easier, or rockets for greater firepower, but necessitating greater handling skills (which isn't easy when you're dodging missiles yourself) is a choice worth making and if you make a poor choice, you'll find out quickly (and possibly painfully) enough.To do well, you'll have to work out approach and escape routes as often enough you'll find yourself sneaking around a building corner to come face to face with a flak-armed Walrus, having to flee, dropping down to wave-skimming height with Hell's fury erupting around and behind you as you limp back to the carrier to repair and try again.  There's a frisson to these moments that is well worth experiencing.Is it worth the full asking price of £20?  Maybe not, but it's definitely worth playing, and one run through of the Campaign (linear story) and the Strategy Game (non-linear island hopping campaign) will keep you entertained for a fair few hours.  If you're willing to add mods, that might make the Strategy Game worth playing through a second time, but basically all they'll do is increase the difficulty (and remove some possible exploits) as opposed to introducing anything really new.There's a free demo available, so try the game out and work out what price you think the game is worth.  There are plenty of newer games with more bugs and less polish being given far better reviews than this received upon its release.8/10 - Would fly backwards into trees again.

												I want to like this game. I really want to.When I saw the concept of a strategy games with highly customizable units that you can control by yourself, I was amazed. The graphics are nice - nothing awe-inspiring, but they more than suffice. The scenery on multiple occasions looks like you'd want to go on a holiday there. I lost quite a few units just staring into a magnificent sunset over an idyllic archipelago, not noticing how a hostile attack chopper moved in to engage. The guys designing the islands really put a lot of effort into making the islands beautiful and fun to drive over in first person.Engaging the enemy requires moving with care, you need to manage the ammunition and fuel of your units and be on guard for counterattacks, which makes for a nice challenge - so far, Carrier Command: Gaea Mission seemed like a great revival of an old classic to me.Where the game lost me was the tank/APC AI. That's not an artificial intelligence, it's an artificial stupidity. Your ground units are apparently incapable of doing proper pathfinding while not on the dirt roads on the island. they fail to engage clearly visible enemies and often cause more damage to allied units than to the enemy.The aiming when controlling a vehicle feels like the most sloppy console port I have ever played, sucking the fun out of controlling units yourself after less than 30 minutes - which is just made worse by the fact that you *have* to do that since there is no AI that could do it.To make matters worse, the endgame is incredibly bothersome and dragged out to the point where you just stop playing after a certain point, because there is no real motivation to keep going. What you do will always be the same, you can outplay the enemy with ease and take an entire Island with a single fighter when fully equipped, but still cave to land and refuel a dozen times. At that point, the game stops being fun and slows down to a painfully slow grind.I really like the concept. I really like the scenery. I like the way the units were designed. I like how it feels if you mount a massive howitzer on every single of your vehicles and simultaneously open fire on a docked enemy carrier and watching it burst into flames trying to escape. I like how it feels to finally defeat the heaviest type of island defence grid there is.But Everything else about this game is just so much off.If this game would allow your friends to join your game, take control of a unit and seize an island together, this game would be much more fun. If the AI could actually put up a fight, making it unnecessary to just spam units at you, it would be so much more fun. If the controls were responsive and not so prone to oversteering, fighting inside a controlled unit would be so much less exhausting.But it sadly isn't like that.If some dev reads this, please see if you can somehow try to do something about it. Everything I see in this game screams of the passion, enthusiasm and heart you poured into this game, and I think I can see what you hoped it could become - and I'm to this day still dreamy about it. If you think you can fix some of the issues with this game, please give it a try - I am certain this game is worth it.But until then, I sadly can't in good faith recommend this game to anyone just stepping by looking through the steam store.Maybe you don't mind the grind, maybe you are okay with an AI that needs a guiding hand 75% of the time, and maybe you're not bothered that much by the things that bothered me so much, and you love games with good scenery that make you want to take a screenshot to print on a postcard - in that case, this game might be something for you.But before you really choose to spend money on it, be aware that this game has some big flaws.
